Social stratification and groupings</topcClas>       </subject>       <abstract><p>Abstract copyright UK Data Service and data collection copyright owner.</p>The <i>Young Life and Times Survey</i> (YLT) originally began as a companion survey to the <I>Northern Ireland Life and Times Survey</I> series (available at the UK Data Archive under GN 33235). From 1998-2000, YLT surveyed young people aged 12-17 living in the households of adults interviewed for NILT. Subsequently, YLT underwent evaluation in 2001 and was relaunched in 2003 (see SN 4826), independent of the adult NILT and using a completely different methodology. From this point, YLT has used Child Benefit records as a sampling frame and contacts all young people whose 16th birthday falls in February of the survey year. Although a few questions are asked that are also included in NILT, the rest of the survey now covers different topics.<br> <br> The aims of the YLT series are to:<ul><li>monitor public attitudes towards social policy and political issues in Northern Ireland</li><li>provide a time series on attitudes to key social policy areas</li><li>facilitate academic social policy analysis</li><li>provide a freely available resource on public attitudes for the wider community of users in Northern Ireland</li><li>give a voice to young people</li></ul>An open access time-series teaching dataset has been created from the 2003-2012 YLTs - see SN 7548.<br> <br> Further information about the YLT, including publications, may be found on the Access Research Knowledge (ARK) <a href="http://www.ark.ac.uk/nilt/ylt/index.html" title="Young Life and Times Survey">YLT</a> webpages.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract>The <I>Young Life and Times Survey, 2003-2012: Teaching Dataset</I> is part of a suite of teaching and learning resources created as part of a Higher Education Academy (HEA) strategic project focusing on teaching research methods.  The project <a href="https://www.heacademy.ac.uk/disciplines/Soc_Sci/TRM_ProjectReports_2012-13-1" title="Learning by numbers: new open educational resources for teaching quantitative methods">Learning by numbers: new open educational resources for teaching quantitative methods</a> involved the creation of new teaching datasets from two major surveys focusing on Northern Ireland, with accompanying 'student-friendly' documentation and teaching guidelines. Specifically, two teaching datasets were created using NILT 2012 (see SNs 7546 and 7547) as well as this time-series teaching dataset drawing on the YLT 2003-2012 surveys. Documentation combining an edited technical report and codebook accompanies the teaching datasets. This documentation includes details of all the variables included in the teaching datasets as well as a summary technical report, with the main issues outlines in accessible language, for example, research design, sampling and response rates. Teaching guidelines drawing upon the particular variables included in the datasets are also available.  <br> <br> This dataset is based on YLT 2003-2012, and adapted for the purposes of this project. Some variables have been constructed and/or simplified for this teaching dataset \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd notes are provided in the codebook.  While the teaching datasets contains the same total number of respondents, they are intended for teaching purposes only; it is advisable to use the original YLT annual studies for research (see SNs 4826, 5175, 5338, 5674, 5818, 6274, 6531, 6820, 7058 and 7409). Further information about the teaching datasets may be found on the <a href="http://www.ark.ac.uk/teaching/teachqm.html" title="ARK Teaching datasets: Learning by numbers">ARK Teaching datasets: Learning by numbers</a> webpage.<br> <br> </abstract>       <abstract><B>Main Topics</B>:<br>Topics covered include attitudes to religion, religious identity, inter-faith and community relations, future expectations, and demographic details.</abstract>       <sumDscr>         <collDate event="start" date="2003-01-01T00:00:00Z">2003</collDate>         <collDate event="end" date="2012-01-01T00:00:00Z">2012</collDate>         <nation>Northern Ireland</nation>         <geogUnit>No spatial unit</geogUnit>         <anlyUnit>Individuals</anlyUnit>         <universe>National</universe>         <universe>Northern Irish young people</universe>         <universe>Respondents to YLT surveys conducted between 2003-2012. The respondents would have been aged 16 and resident in Northern Ireland at the time of the individual YLT survey.</universe>         <dataKind>Numeric data</dataKind>         <dataKind> Individual (micro) level</dataKind>       </sumDscr>     </stdyInfo>     <method>       <dataColl>         <timeMeth>Repeated cross-sectional study</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>The YLT 2003-2012 and NILT 2012 teaching datasets were created as part of a single project.</timeMeth>         <timeMeth>Some survey questions are repeated annually.</timeMeth>         <dataCollector>Schubotz, D., Queen's University of Belfast. School of Sociology, Social Policy and Social Work</dataCollector>         <sampProc>Simple random sample</sampProc>         <deviat>9,168 cases</deviat>         <collMode>Telephone interview; Postal survey; Compilation or synthesis of existing material</collMode>         <collMode>The teaching dataset is a simplified subset created from YLT 2003-2012; see documentation for details.</collMode>         <sources />         <weight>No weighting used</weight>         <cleanOps>A*</cleanOps>       </dataColl>     </method>     <dataAccs>       <setAvail>         <accsPlac>UK Data Service</accsPlac>       </setAvail>       <useStmt>         <specPerm>Open</specPerm>         <restrctn>The depositor has specified that registration is not required.</restrctn>         <contact><a href=http://www.ukdataservice.ac.uk/help/get-in-touch.aspx>Get in touch</a></contact>         <conditions>These data are available to any user for any purpose under the <a href="http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/4.0/" title="Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International Licence CC BY-SA 4.0)">Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International Licence (CC BY-SA 4.0)</a></conditions>       </useStmt>     </dataAccs>     <othrStdyMat>       <relStdy>4213 Young Life and Times Survey, 1999 </relStdy>       <relStdy>4230 Young Life and Times Survey, 1998 </relStdy>       <relStdy>4495 Young Life and Times Survey, 2000 </relStdy>       <relStdy>4826 Young Life and Times Survey, 2003 </relStdy>       <relStdy>5175 Young Life and Times Survey, 2004 </relStdy>       <relStdy>5338 Young Life and Times Survey, 2005 </relStdy>       <relStdy>5674 Young Life and Times Survey, 2006 </relStdy>       <relStdy>5818 Young Life and Times Survey, 2007 </relStdy>       <relStdy>6274 Young Life and Times Survey, 2008 </relStdy>       <relStdy>6531 Young Life and Times Survey, 2009 </relStdy>       <relStdy>6820 Young Life and Times Survey, 2010 </relStdy>       <relStdy>7058 Young Life and Times Survey, 2011 </relStdy>       <relStdy>7409 Young Life and Times Survey, 2012 </relStdy>       <relStdy>7541 Young Life and Times Survey, 2013 </relStdy>       <relPubl>McNamee, H., Lloyd, K. and Schubotz, D.
